author: By Ian Austen and Ian Willms
title: A Public Park or Private Spa: A City Debates the Future of an Island Oasis
description: Officials in Toronto and many residents ask why the province of Ontario is turning a former waterfront park over to an Austrian spa operator.
content: It was an unusually mild winter day in Toronto, but that did not make Lake Ontario’s icy waters any more inviting. Still, Sara Fruchtman, wearing a bathing suit and a bathing cap, plunged into the lake at Michael Hough Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,073, May 27, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Steps Up a Covert Sabotage Campaign Aimed at Europe
description: Russian military intelligence, the G.R.U., is behind arson attacks aimed at undermining support for Ukraine’s war effort, security officials say.
content: U.S. and allied intelligence officials are tracking an increase in low-level sabotage operations in Europe that they say are part of a Russian campaign to undermine support for Ukraine’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia Plans New Offensive in Ukraine’s Northeast, Zelensky Says
description: Moscow is again amassing forces near the border, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine warned. His comments came as officials said that a Russian strike had killed at least 16 people in Kharkiv.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said on Sunday that Moscow’s forces were massing for a new ground offensive on the northeast of his country, a day after a Russian missile strike on a hardware superstore in the city of Kharkiv killed at least 16 people and wounded dozens more, according to Ukrainian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Fetterman, Flashing a Sharper Edge, Keeps Picking Fights With the Left
description: The first-term Pennsylvanian has battled with progressives on Israel, immigration and energy, adopting a more caustic political persona and alienating some supporters.
content: Senator John Fetterman was hard to miss, lumbering down an empty hallway in a Senate office building dressed in his signature baggy gym shorts and a black hoodie. So when Stevie O’Hanlon, an environmentalist and organizer from Chester County, Pa., spotted him recently, she took the opportunity to question her home-state senator about a pipeline in her community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Optimistic About the War in Ukraine, Putin Unleashes a Purge at Home
description: Despite years of criticism, President Vladimir V. Putin has only now changed his defense minister and allowed high-level corruption arrests.
content: Periodic outcries over incompetence and corruption at the top of the Russian military have dogged President Vladimir V. Putin’s war effort since the start of his invasion of Ukraine in early 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Even as Violent Crime Drops, Lawlessness Rises as an Election Issue
description: In most cities, rates of homicide and violent assault are down significantly from pandemic-era highs. But property crimes have risen, fueling voter anxiety.
content: In mid-2020, the country was reeling from a surge in violent crime and civil upheaval after the killing of George Floyd by the police — a knife’s-edge national crisis that President Donald J. Trump made a central issue in the run-up to Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 351, May 27, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Skyscraper Refurbished in Miniature and Memory
description: A model of The New York Times’s old headquarters in Times Square was missing the gargoyles that once adorned the building. Enter a graphics editor with a passion on the side.
content: One corner of the Museum at The Times is devoted to Times Tower, a slender building in Times Square that was the headquarters of The New York Times from 1905 to 1913. (Much transformed, the building is known today as 1 Times Square.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Louise Johns
title: Big Sky, Big Growth: How Montana’s Newcomers Are Shaping Its Senate Duel
description: Out-of-state transplants, drawn during the pandemic by the Mountain West’s allure, have caused prices to soar and created new uncertainty in the state’s crucial Senate race.
content: Growing up in Bozeman, Mont., Dylan Heintz loved the picturesque views of the snow-capped mountains and the small-town charm. Things were cheap: His dad bought the family home for about $80,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fred A. Bernstein
title: Sanford L. Smith, Creator of Prestigious Art Fairs, Dies at 84
description: Over four decades, he produced more than 150 events. Some dealers reported selling more in a weekend at a Smith fair than in a year in their galleries.
content: Sanford L. Smith, an art lover and entrepreneur who created some of New York’s most prestigious art and design fairs,  generating millions of dollars in sales and drawing attention to previously overlooked areas of art, died on Saturday at a senior living facility in Manhattan. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Idaho Drag Performer Wins Over $1.1 Million in Defamation Suit Against Blogger
description: The jury unanimously sided with the performer in a case against a blogger who made false claims that the artist had exposed himself to a crowd at a pride event in 2022.
content: A drag performer in Idaho won more than $1.1 million in damages on Friday in a defamation lawsuit against a blogger who falsely claimed that he had exposed himself to a crowd that included children at an event two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Reebok Isn’t a ‘Hobby’ for Shaquille O’Neal
description: After pushing to be in charge of the company’s return to basketball, the Hall of Famer understands the stakes. “If this doesn’t work, everyone’s leaving,” he said.
content: In mid-March, Reebok staged its annual brand summit for about 500 business partners at the Artists for Humanity EpiCenter, an events space in Boston, where Todd Krinsky, the company’s chief executive, was harboring a secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Veteran Survives Grizzly’s Attack After It Bites Into Can of Bear Spray
description: Shayne Patrick Burke, a disabled veteran in the Army Reserve, said the attack was “the most violent” thing he had experienced, including being shot at.
content: Shayne Patrick Burke was on a short hike this month to photograph owls in the backcountry of Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming when he spotted a grizzly bear cub about 50 to 70 yards in front of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: Savoring the Summer at 5 Waterside Hotels
description: Whether it’s by a lake or an ocean, or in a castle or a cottage, here are places where the water is never far.
content: Nothing says summer more than a waterfront getaway. And at these five properties you can make the most of the season, whether you want to splash in the ocean off the Maine coast, paddle board across a reservoir in upstate New York, kayak in a Rhode Island bay, or laze by a river on a South Carolina island. You can even skirt the crowds in Europe’s capitals by escaping to the mountains of Austria where a castle on a lake awaits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lyna Bentahar
title: Summer Begins
description: Memorial Day is the starting gun of a new season. Here’s a guide on how to spend the summer months.
content: Memorial Day is a starting gun. While other holidays can be like a finish line — the culmination of so much energy — Memorial Day marks the beginning. The whole summer stretches out in front of us, a track shimmering in the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Furiosa’ Is a Box Office Dud, Adding to Hollywood Woes
description: Memorial Day weekend ticket sales in North America are expected to total $125 million, down 40 percent from last year.
content: Hollywood expected “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga” to scorch the box office over the holiday weekend. Instead, the big-budget Warner Bros. prequel iced it over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Post-Verdict Playbook: Anger and Retribution, Regardless of the Outcome
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has a history of attacking investigators, blaming President Biden and seeking vengeance on those who cross him.
content: The verdict in former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial remains a mystery, at least for a few more days. Less of a mystery is what Mr. Trump will say and do after it is announced — whatever the outcome might be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: With ‘We Are Lady Parts,’ Nida Manzoor Rocks On
description: “Silliness is hugely important to me,” said the writer, whose comedy about a Muslim female punk band has won awards and challenged stereotypes.
content: When the writer-director Nida Manzoor began dreaming up Season 2 of “We Are Lady Parts,” the comedy about an all-female Muslim punk band, one of her earliest ideas was a song: “Malala Made Me Do It,” a neo-Western hype track celebrating the activist Malala Yousafzai. And then she had another idea: Maybe she could get Malala, whom she had met briefly at a talk, to star in the video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: The Hard Problem of Bringing Trump Into Focus
description: For all the news that the former president makes, the Biden team is struggling to make the campaign about him.
content: The video shows Donald Trump standing at a gilded lectern in Mar-a-Lago. It’s December, a week or so before Christmas, and the former president is addressing a group of donors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Has a Decision to Make
description: Her craziest-clown-at-the-carnival act seems to have descended into a sad clown party of one.
content: Marjorie Taylor Greene seems even thirstier for attention than usual. The Georgia congresswoman recently caused a rumpus in a House Oversight Committee meeting by mocking the eyelashes of a Democratic colleague, Jasmine Crockett. (The episode went viral. Of course.) Days later Ms. Greene dialed up the lunacy, claiming knowledge of a deep state plot to assassinate Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: How a Profane Joke on Twitter Spawned a Legal Army
description: A litigation team built from the sharpest, funniest tweeters is suing Elon Musk.
content: Here’s one way to build a legal team: Interview graduates from the top law schools or firms, then hire the most qualified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Freda Moon
title: 6 Beaches for Budding Swimmers, Surfers and Castle Builders
description: For families with children, we found half a dozen beaches in the United States and Mexico, each tailored to a particular summer activity.
content: A family beach vacation is an American classic. But depending on their children’s ages and inclinations, some families may be drawn to different kinds of shorelines: those featuring clear, calm water for snorkeling and learning to swim; or, for shell collectors and young naturalists, sandy stretches carpeted with seashells or bordered by tide pools. For castle builders, fine sand is a must, while would-be surfers need tidy waves, ready to ride. Here are six great beaches in the United States and Baja California for family-favorite summer activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Amateur Historians Heard Tales of a Lost Tudor Palace. Then, They Dug It Up.
description: In a small English village, a group of dedicated locals has unearthed the remains of a long-vanished palace that had been home to Henry VIII’s grandmother.
content: For generations, residents of Collyweston — a village in central England snuggled up against the River Welland — passed down stories of a grand Tudor palace, of royal processions through the valley below, of the mother of a king who had called it home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Richard Sherman, Songwriter of Many Spoonfuls of Sugar, Dies at 95
description: He and his brother, Robert, teamed up to write the songs for “Mary Poppins” and other Disney classics. They also gave the world “It’s a Small World (After All).”
content: Richard M. Sherman, the younger brother in a songwriting team that won two Oscars and two Grammys, brought Disney movies to musical life and gave the world numbers like “A Spoonful of Sugar,” “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious” and the ubiquitous, multiply translated “It’s a Small World (After All),” died on Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Do Not Allow Putin to Capture Another Pawn in Europe
description: Georgia’s new law against “foreign influence” is actually a troubling sign of Putin’s influence in Ukraine’s neighbors.
content: The Georgians call it the Russian Law. It was passed recently by the Parliament in the Republic of Georgia, purportedly to improve transparency by having civil society and media groups that get some of their funds from abroad register as groups “carrying the interests of a foreign power.” But the tens of thousands of Georgians who have taken to the streets again and again against the law know its real goal — to suppress those who would hold the government to account, and to move the country into the orbit of Vladimir Putin’s Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: The New Number One Guy in the Group
description: “Summer House” star West Wilson wasn’t expecting the Bravoverse to fall in love with him. They did anyway.
content: West Wilson never thought he’d be spending the summer in a house in the Hamptons, let alone as part of a reality television show. The unemployed former football player from Missouri was about to run out of money following a three-week boys’ trip when he got a call that would change his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Lobrano
title: From Waiter to Guest at Nantucket’s Grande Dame Hotel
description: A writer returns to a classic Massachusetts hotel, where he worked 50 years ago, to ponder how he, the island, and the newly refurbished inn, have changed.
content: In the summer of 1974, I was working as a waiter at the White Elephant, the grande dame of Nantucket hotels, a rambling gray-shingled pile that sits right on the island’s harbor. One muggy August night, I sent the six lobster dinners ordered by Francis Sargent, the governor of Massachusetts and his guests crashing to the floor when some butter on the heel of my hand propelled my tray off the stand I’d been kneeling to set it down on. Thinking about it still makes me cringe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: ‘Contact. I.E.D.’
description: In war, death interrupts nothing. Time doesn’t stop; it seems to accelerate.
content: “Contact. I.E.D.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Pragati K.B. and Hari Kumar
title: Two Deadly Fires in Rapid Succession Expose India’s Gaps in Safety
description: Disasters over the weekend that claimed at least 34 lives prompted condolences, arrests and finger-pointing. But systemic change remains elusive, analysts say.
content: Seven newborn babies lost their lives after their New Delhi neonatal clinic was engulfed in flames. What remained of the two-story building on Sunday morning was its burned facade, a charred spiral staircase and oxygen cylinders covered in soot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Last Line of Defense for a Key Eastern Town
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 26, 2024.
content: “We have an absolutely absurd situation. Imagine a boxing match where there are equal boxers but one of them can hit once while his opponent can hit 10 times.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Foster Children Fight to Stop States From Taking Federal Benefits
description: A longstanding practice of using a child’s federal survivor and disability benefits to defray the cost of foster care is under scrutiny in Congress and statehouses.
content: James Wood’s mother struggled with addiction, and he often found himself adrift, not knowing what day or month it was. “I didn’t understand how time worked,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Debating the Best Way to Fix Social Security
description: Readers discuss Peter Coy’s proposal to reduce benefits. Also: Singapore’s view; an Ithaca man’s tragic death; MSNBC’s role in our democracy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Simple, Summery, Spicy Grilled Shrimp
description: And if it’s cool and overcast: bo ssam, cured and slow roasted and served with lettuce, rice and a raft of condiments.
content: Good morning. How I’m hoping it will go today: light wind from the southwest, sun high in a cloudless sky, low tide around 2 p.m., a striped bass slipping along the creek where I’m staked out and inhaling the crab fly I’ve put right in front of her with an effortless cast. How it will undoubtedly go: hard wind from the east, sun blanketed by dark clouds if not sheets of rain, and some problem discovered that will keep me off the water anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Don Perlin, Comic Book Artist Who Found Success Late, Dies at 94
description: His Moon Knight was a hit in the 1970s, 30 years after he began his career. Bloodshot, another popular superhero, followed two decades later.
content: Don Perlin, a veteran comic book artist who, after decades in the industry, helped create the popular but nontraditional superheroes Moon Knight and Bloodshot, died on May 14 in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phil Klay
title: How Should We Honor the Dead of Our Failed Wars?
description: We owe it to the dead to remember what mattered to them, and the ideals they held, as well as how those ideals were betrayed.
content: About 10 years ago, as the war in Afghanistan was slowly, painfully winding down, I walked through Arlington National Cemetery with a fellow Marine veteran and a relative of mine visiting from Ireland. We passed row after row of pristine white tombs, the dead of all the just wars and unjust wars that made and remade this country, and my relative told us he found it quite moving; he hadn’t been expecting that. Perhaps he thought it’d be more bombastic, or obviously militaristic, and he was taken by the beauty and serenity and quiet dignity of the place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: In Most Cases
description: Christopher Youngs’s crossword is more than the sum of its parts.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Monday Briefing: Ukraine Fears a Russian Push Near Kharkiv
description: Also, Hamas fires missiles at central Israel
content: A day after at least 16 people were killed in what officials said was a Russian missile strike on a hardware superstore in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said that Moscow’s forces were massing for a new ground offensive in the northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 26, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 26, 2024.
content: An article on May 12 about early retirement referred imprecisely to one aspect of Jackie Cummings Koski’s childhood. While she grew up near the poverty line, her family did not use food stamps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: A Medium-Rare Goodbye
description: Pietro’s, an old-guard Italian steakhouse, said farewell to its longtime address in Midtown Manhattan with a crew of regulars.
content: Waiters in blue jackets wended through a crowded dining room balancing trays of martinis. A woman ran her fingers along a wall covered with markings of the heights of children. Longtime regulars handed servers farewell tips through firm handshakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fintan O'Toole
title: Man, the Last 50 Years or So Have Been a Wild Time for Statecraft
description: Stuart E. Eizenstat has served half a dozen U.S. presidents and made a lot of friends. In “The Art of Diplomacy,” he lays out some of their teachable moments.
content: When I was growing up in Catholic Ireland, books on moral and theological matters carried, near their title pages, a mark of approval from a local bishop and the phrase “nihil obstat” — a fancy Latin way of saying “all clear.” Stuart E. Eizenstat’s book on the major episodes of American diplomacy over the last half-century — from the opening of China to the invasion of Gaza — comes with nihil obstats from the secular equivalent of an entire conclave of cardinals.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Had Gotten a Fantastic Deal on a Floor-Model Cruiser Bike’
description: A helper’s quick comeback, tying up loose ends on the No. 4 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Vivek Shankar
title: Aid Deliveries From Egypt Resume Going Into Gaza
description: Under a U.S.-brokered agreement, Egypt allowed trucks to pass through the Israeli-controlled Kerem Shalom.
content: Aid trucks from Egypt entered the Gaza Strip on Sunday under a new U.S.-brokered agreement to reopen a vital conduit for humanitarian relief, the Israeli military and the Egyptian Red Crescent said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky and Mitra Taj
title: Peru Issued a Decree Calling Trans Identity a ‘Disorder.’ A Backlash Followed.
description: Government officials say the regulation was intended to expand mental health care access for transgender people. Activists say it will increase discrimination.
content: The bulletin appeared without much fanfare in an official government newspaper in Peru that publishes new laws and regulations. Peruvian health officials say they had no idea the response it would trigger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: Dark and Stormy Is How They Take Their Décor
description: Some decorators swear by the calming effects of deep and moody hues.
content: When Emily Peterson purchased her seaside cottage in Cape Neddick, Maine, she knew its coastal hues had to go. “The second we walked through this house, I had this vision that I wanted it to be dark,” said Ms. Peterson, who bought the 1770s home nearly two years ago. “It’s been here for so many years and I just wanted to bring life back into it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Alex Travelli
title: Free Food? Modi Makes Sure Every Indian Knows Whom to Thank for It.
description: India’s welfare programs improve lives. Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party uses its vast machinery to ensure the handouts also create loyal voters.
content: Durga Prasad, an 80-year-old farmer, was resting under the shade of a tree in front of his home when the party workers came. An app on their smartphones could tell them in an instant who Mr. Prasad was, whom he might vote for — and why he should be grateful to India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jo Becker and Adam Sella
title: The Hamas Chief and the Israeli Who Saved His Life
description: In an Israeli prison infirmary, a Jewish dentist came to the aid of a desperately ill Hamas inmate. Years later, the prisoner became a mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack.
content: This is how Dr. Yuval Bitton remembers the morning of Oct. 7. Being jolted awake just after sunrise by the insistent ringing of his phone. The frantic voice of his daughter, who was traveling abroad, asking, “Dad, what’s happened in Israel? Turn on the TV.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nora Walsh
title: Learning to Surf, 200 Miles From the Nearest Ocean
description: With consistent conditions, affordable prices and a friendly vibe, a wave pool in Waco, Texas, proved to be an ideal place for a beginner to find her footing.
content: I paddled hard to stay in front of the two-foot wave, repeating the sequence of movements I’d just practiced on land. Press hands beneath shoulders, keep chest up, drive knee forward, plant back foot, then pop up into a crouch like a sprinter ready to take off. As I eased onto my feet, the wave crested and propelled me forward: I was surfing! My heart fluttered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: 12 Injured After Turbulence on Flight From Qatar to Ireland
description: The Dublin Airport said that a Qatar Airways flight from Doha landed in Ireland after a dozen people were injured by turbulence.
content: Twelve people were injured on Sunday during turbulence on a Qatar Airways flight from Doha that landed safely as scheduled in Ireland, the Dublin Airport said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: What Joan Nathan Taught Me About the Power of Showing Up
description: How to be there for a friend in need.
content: Three-quarters of the way through a grueling 10-day hospital stay for my older daughter, Orli, the cookbook author Joan Nathan called me from hospital reception. Her daughter, she said, had read about Orli’s latest surgery via social media. Could I come downstairs?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: What Happened to Our Ad-Free TV?
description: Ads are here, there — almost everywhere — on streaming services now.
content: Not long ago, streaming TV came with a promise: Sign up, and commercials will be a thing of the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tony Pipa
title: Biden Wants to Send Billions to Rural America. But This Must Happen First.
description: All that money is meaningless unless it reaches local communities.
content: President Biden regularly emphasizes how the major pieces of legislation he has signed — the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, the CHIPS and Science Act, and the Inflation Reduction Act — expand opportunities for Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Don’t Let a Bird’s Feathers Fool You
description: From sibling murder to snakes for breakfast, birds’ lives may be darker than you imagine.
content: I saw a couple of crows dining on roadkill the other day as I was driving by and wondered, Does this count as bird-watching?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: Hundreds of Readers Told Us Their Favorite Soundtracks. Which Came Out on Top?
description: Music that accompanied movies from the 1980s and ’90s dominated the recommendations, though sometimes the films themselves were beside the point.
content: Are soundtracks making a comeback? The idea of a movie-related compilation of choice tunes that add up to a distinct vibe seemed to go out of fashion after the early 2000s, when the music for “Garden State” was such an event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon, Isabella Kwai and Johnny Diaz
title: Storms Kill 18 in Southern Plains as Severe Weather Moves East
description: Deaths were reported in Arkansas, Kentucky, Oklahoma and Texas after powerful storms swept through. Millions of Americans were under the threat of more severe weather Sunday.
content: Powerful storms and possible tornadoes pummeled parts of Texas, Kentucky, Oklahoma and Arkansas on Saturday night, killing at least 18 people, damaging homes and leaving hundreds of thousands without power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Death Toll in Papua New Guinea Landslide Estimated to Be at Least 670
description: More than 48 hours after the disaster, its full extent remains unclear, with aid slow to reach survivors and conditions on the ground still dangerous.
content: At least 670 people are assumed to have died after a landslide in Papua New Guinea, according to a local United Nations official. The landslide hit a rural region of the island nation early Friday, but search-and-rescue efforts have been hampered by difficulty in reaching the disaster site and by the hazard that the shifting ground continues to pose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: An Editor Whose Business Is Fitness
description: Molly Mirhashem, an editor on the Well desk, wants to motivate readers of all ages and experience levels.
content: Molly Mirhashem is used to running around in circles — literally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohammad Ali
title: I’m an Indian Muslim, and I’m Scared to Say So
description: In Modi’s Hindu-nationalist India, Muslims have to deny who we are.
content: I used to answer the phone with “Salam.” Not anymore. I don’t want people to know I’m a Muslim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Rubin
title: Sand, Sea and as Much Serenity as You Could Ever Want
description: The bluffs, dunes and lagoons of the Magdalens, a colorful yet tranquil island chain north of Prince Edward Island, are far from everywhere. That’s the point.
content: They tell a story in the Magdalen Islands about a winter so bitter that they were completely cut off, with no way to guide their boats through the frozen harbors.
source.name: The New York Times
